text:
Admission Date:  [**2144-8-11**]              Discharge Date:   [**2144-8-22**]

Date of Birth:  [**2075-9-5**]             Sex:   F

Service: MEDICINE

Allergies:
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Simvastatin

Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 7333**]
Chief Complaint:
shortness of breath

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
TEE with Cardioversion
BIV ICD placement

History of Present Illness:
Ms. [**Known lastname 7962**] is a 68 yo F with PMH of nonischemic cardiomyopathy
(EF 25% on [**2-/2144**]), HTN, mitral valve prolapse, intermittent
LBBB, and atrial fibrillation who has been having progressively
worsening SOB for the last 3 days secondary to CHF exacerbation.
Patient states that she initially noticed SOB approximately 2
weeks ago while she was on vacation in NH.  She attributed this
to humidity.  She does note that she was eating more salt that
usual given dining out.  Also noticed intermittent heart
palpitations.  She went to the ER on [**2144-8-3**] with SOB.  She was
seen by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] in consult and given improvement of SOB
after Lasix, advised that she can be discharged home.  Patient
also saw Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 73**] in clinic on [**8-6**] at which time she was
not SOB, lungs were clear and she did not have any lower
extremity edema.  At that time, several medication changes were
made.  She was started on Coumadin, Metoprolol was discontinued
and she was started instead on Carvedilol 6.25mg [**Hospital1 **].  Patient
instead self titrated the metoprolol to 50mg daily and had been
taking carvedilol 3.12 daily.
.
On Saturday [**8-8**], she again developed SOB with minimal exertion
and with lying flat.  Breathing better with sitting upright.
Positive PND.  This morning, noticed swelling in her ankles. Has
also had intermittent palpitations.  Denies any chest pain.
lightheadedness.  Although patient states she has never had
symptoms of SOB with exertion, OMR note documents that she
reported some SOB with walking up the stairs in 4/[**2143**].
.
In the ED, initial vitals were 96.8 54 128/85 32 90s%.  Patient
was placed on 3L NC, O2 sats remained stable, no SOB at rest,
some with getting out of bed. Labs and imaging significant for
BNP elevated to [**Numeric Identifier 7963**], INR suptherapeutic at 1.4, Na 129, K 5.4.
 CXR with cardiomegaly with right infrahilar airspace opacity,
looks like pneumonia vs. pulmonary edema. Patient given Lasix
20mg IV x2 at 7am, put out 800cc.Vitals on transfer were 114
AFib occas PVCs, 98.5 temp, 98% 3L NC, RR 16, 110/79.
.
On arrival to the floor, patient feels well.  States SOB has
resolved after treatment with Lasix.  Denies SOB, chest pain,
palpitations, lightheadedness.  No recent fevers/chills.  Does
have a dry cough which is chronic in setting of postnasal drip.
No dysuria.  No recent changes in vision, no dysarthia, no loss
of sensation/motor function.
.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain,
dyspnea on exertion, syncope or presyncope.

Past Medical History:
-Hypertension
-Atrial fibrillation on coumadin
-Mitral valve prolapse
-Intermittent left bundle branch block
-Nonischemic cardiomyopathy with EF 25% on TTE [**2144-2-24**] with
elevated pulmonary artery systolic pressure and moderate MR.

Social History:
-Tobacco history: 20 pack yr history, quit 30 years
-ETOH: denies
-Illicit drugs: denies

Family History:
Father: HTN, stroke at 50
Paternal aunt: MI at age 48, passed away
Mother: heart disease in 80s
Sisters: HTN

Physical Exam:
Physical Exam on Admission:
.
VS: T=94.6 (?) BP=125/65 HR=86 RR=18 O2 sat 98 RA
GENERAL: WDWN F in NAD.
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. EOMI.
NECK: Supple with JVP of 7 cm.
CARDIAC: irregularly irregular rhythm, no m/r/g appreciated
LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp
were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Crackles in right base,
wheezes or rhonchi.
ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND.
EXTREMITIES: trace pitting edema in [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **]/l
SKIN: erythematous macular rash on abdomen, breasts, lower back,
non pruritic
PULSES:
Right: Carotid 2+ DP 2+ PT 2+
Left: Carotid 2+  DP 2+ PT 2+

Pertinent Results:
Labs on Admission:

[**2144-8-11**] 06:12AM   WBC-6.1 RBC-4.13* HGB-13.2 HCT-38.9 MCV-94
MCH-32.1* MCHC-34.0 RDW-15.0
[**2144-8-11**] 06:12AM   NEUTS-70.2* LYMPHS-17.6* MONOS-10.0 EOS-1.8
BASOS-0.3
[**2144-8-11**] 06:12AM   PT-17.2* PTT-26.5 INR(PT)-1.5*
[**2144-8-11**] 06:12AM   GLUCOSE-130* UREA N-27* CREAT-1.1 SODIUM-129*
POTASSIUM-5.4* CHLORIDE-95* TOTAL CO2-23 ANION GAP-16
[**2144-8-11**] 03:06PM   CALCIUM-10.1 PHOSPHATE-4.5 MAGNESIUM-1.9
[**2144-8-11**] 06:12AM   proBNP-[**Numeric Identifier 7963**]*
[**2144-8-11**] 06:12AM   cTropnT-<0.01
.
Imaging
CXR [**2144-8-22**]:

Impression: The current study demonstrates biventricular pacing
devices with the leads most likely located in the right atrium,
right ventricle and the left epicardial vein in expected
location. Cardiomegaly is moderate to severe, unchanged.
Mediastinum is unremarkable. No pneumothorax is seen. Small
amount of pleural effusion is noted most likely on the right.

ECG [**8-11**]: Atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.
Left bundle-branch block with a single narrowly conducted QRS
complex. The axis is right inferior. Since previous tracing the
single narrow complex beat is new. Despite a more rapid
ventricular response, the axis is the same. One should verify
that the limb leads were properly placed. Clinical correlation
is suggested.
.
Chest X-ray [**8-11**]:
FINDINGS: The heart size is enlarged, apparently slightly
increased from
prior study, this maybe the magnifying effect of AP projection.
The
mediastinal contours again demonstrate calcified atherosclerotic
disease of the aortic knob. Cephalization of pulmonary
vasculature is accompanied by interstitial edema. The lungs
demonstrate airspace opacity in the right
infrahilar region. Additionally, subtle blunting of the
bilateral
costophrenic angles persist, compatible with small pleural
effusions. Thereis no pneumothorax.

IMPRESSION: Cardiomegaly with interstitial edema; right
infrahilar airspace
opacity may reflect asymmetric pulmonary edema, but follow up
radiographs may be helpful to exclude pneumonia.

Labs on discharge:
[**2144-8-22**] 06:58AM BLOOD WBC-7.5 RBC-3.69* Hgb-12.0 Hct-34.3*
MCV-93 MCH-32.6* MCHC-35.0 RDW-14.8 Plt Ct-206
[**2144-8-22**] 06:58AM BLOOD PT-31.7* PTT-30.9 INR(PT)-3.1*
[**2144-8-22**] 06:58AM BLOOD Glucose-98 UreaN-10 Creat-0.5 Na-128*
K-3.6 Cl-93* HCO3-24 AnGap-15
[**2144-8-22**] 06:58AM BLOOD Calcium-9.5 Phos-3.6 Mg-1.8

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. [**Known lastname 7962**] is a 68 yo F with PMH of nonischemic cardiomyopathy
(EF 25% on [**2-/2144**]), HTN, mitral valve prolapse, intermittent
LBBB, and atrial fibrillation who was admitted for progressively
worsening SOB for the over 3 days secondary to CHF exacerbation.

.
# Cardiac arrest: on [**8-18**], patient was successfully cardioverted
to normal sinus rhythem. She was given a dose of dofetilide.
Later that day it was noted that her QTc was elongated from
previously. That evening, she had a cardiac arrest secondary to
torsades de pointes and ventricular fibrillation. She was
defibrillated after 60 seconds and had ROSC and regained
consciousness. She was briefly transferred to the CCU, where her
magnesium and potassium were repleted and serial EKGs showed
decreasing QTc interval.

# Acute on chronic CHF:  Patient reported history of dyspnea on
exertion, orthopnea, PND and new onset ankle swelling.  Has
known history of CHF with EF 25% in 4/[**2143**]. After receiving
Lasix 40mg IV in the ER, she put out 800cc and dyspnea resolved.
 Initial history and exam consistent with a CHF exacerbation.
[**Month (only) 116**] have baseline worsening EF as she has had such symptoms for
approximately 2 weeks which improved with Lasix.  [**Month (only) 116**] be
secondary to worsening EF in combination with afib with RVR.
Patient's beta blocker was changed on Thursday but she has been
self titrating the medication and not receiving enough beta
blockade.  (Was on Metoprolol XL 100, this was d/c'ed on
Thursday and started on Carvedilol 6.25 mg [**Hospital1 **].  Instead, taking
Metoprolol 50 daily and Carvedilol 3.125 daily.) Therefore, her
rate was not well controlled which is likely stressing the heart
by decreasing adequate forward flow.  Initially, changed to
carvedilol for rate control.  On [**8-15**], carvedilol switched to
metoprolol and rate better controlled. Her metoprolol dose was
adjusted again secondary to her Afib and changed up to metop
150XL. .Patient was optimized on an oral regimen of Lasix prior
to discharge and remained euvolemic. Patient to receive 20meqK
replacement on discharge as well to supplement lasix.
.
# Paroxysmal A-fib/RHYTHM: Patient with known history of atrial
fibrillation.  Rate not well controlled on Carvedilol and
digoxin.  Patient was instead started on metoprolol with much
better rate control.  Just started on Coumadin 5mg qd 5 days
prior to admission. Patient continued anticoagulation with
coumadin throughout stay (dosage adjustments made per INR). PT
had TEE with cardiovesion [**8-18**], initiall successful then patient
developed torsades in the afternoon which responded to
magnesium. Shortly thereafter patient coded with Vfib, with CPR
performed for 1 minute, received one shock and had ROSC. Pt had
continuous Mg replacement. Pt was then brought back to the floor
in stable condition. She continued to be in Afib and had an
increase in her metoprolol dose for rate control. Patient was
then started  Amio gtt and load. She had inital attempt at BIV
ICD placement for LBBB on [**8-20**] which was unsuccessful. The
following day patient had repeat procedure and successful BIV
ICD placement. Patient remained in Afib s/p procedure, and
continued her anticoagulation, and will continue PO amio and
metoprolol for control. Warfarin dose decreased from 6 to 5
prior to discharge due to supratherapuetic INR 3.1. She is to
follow up with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] within the next 2 weeks, and device
clinic on [**8-27**] for evaluation of pacemaker. Pt also will
complete 6 day course of Keflex for pacemaker placement.


# CORONARIES: No history of CAD.  LDL was 147 in 3/[**2143**].  She is
not on a statin because she has function limiting myalgias as a
side effect. Pt started on ASA 81 during hospitilazation and to
continue as outpatient.
.
.
# Hyponatremia: Patient was hyponatremic at 129 on admission, Na
was lowest at 126.  Baseline in last several years (several data
points) has been in the mid to low 130s. Patient was
asymptomatic, mentating well.  [**Month (only) 116**] have been secondary to
combination of diuretics as well as CHF exacerbation leading to
intravascular depletion and ADH secretion.  Na improved with 1.5
L fluid and free water restriction and stabilized. Her Na
returned back to her baseline upon discharge, she is to follow
up with this in clinic.

# Rash: Patient with new macular rash as of morning of admission
on lower abdomen, lower back and breasts.  Denied any new
lotions, detergents.  Did take melatonin day prior to admission
for the first time.  After examination rash appeared to be
fungal in etiology, most c/w with intertrigo. Patient placed on
topical miconazole with improvement in rash.

Transitional Issues:
-Will f/u in device clinic for BIV ICD
-Pt has f/u scheduled with PCP (needs INR and Na checked)
-Pt will get scheduled f/u with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]
[**Name (STitle) 7964**] follow with Cardiologist Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 73**]

Medications on Admission:
Carvedilol 6.25mg PO bid (actually taking [**11-24**] pill once per day
and adding on Metoprolol XL 50)
Hydrochlothiazide 25mg PO qd
Lisinopril 40mg PO qd
Spironolactone 25mg PO qd
Warfarin 5mg PO qd

Discharge Medications:
1. spironolactone 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY
(Daily).
2. lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO HS (at
bedtime).
3. miconazole nitrate 2 % Powder Sig: One (1) Appl Topical [**Hospital1 **]
(2 times a day) as needed for rash.
Disp:*100 mL* Refills:*0*
4. lidocaine 5 %(700 mg/patch) Adhesive Patch, Medicated Sig:
One (1) Adhesive Patch, Medicated Topical DAILY (Daily) as
needed for pain: place for 12 hours, then take off for 12 hours.
Disp:*5 Adhesive Patch, Medicated(s)* Refills:*0*
5. furosemide 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable
PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*60 Tablet, Chewable(s)* Refills:*0*
7. amiodarone 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a
day.
Disp:*180 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
8. cephalexin 500 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q6H (every
6 hours) for 6 days.
Disp:*24 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
9. warfarin 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Once Daily at 4
PM.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
10. metoprolol succinate 100 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr
Sig: 1.5 Tablet Extended Release 24 hrs PO once a day.
Disp:*90 Tablet Extended Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*0*
11. potassium chloride 20 mEq Tablet, ER Particles/Crystals Sig:
One (1) Tablet, ER Particles/Crystals PO once a day.
Disp:*60 Tablet, ER Particles/Crystals(s)* Refills:*0*


Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service

Facility:
[**Hospital 119**] Homecare

Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary:
Congestive heart failure
Atrial fibrillation
Hypertension
Ventricular fibrillation with cardiac arrest

Secondary:
Rash
Hyponatremia


Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.


Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. [**Known lastname 7962**],
.
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your admission to
[**Hospital1 69**].  You came into the
hospital with shortness of breath, which was determined to be
secondary to your congestive heart failure.  You responded well
to Lasix, a diuretic, and your breathing status improved.  Your
hospital course also featured a cardioversion to correct your
heart rate, a cardiac arrest with rescuscitation, and pacemaker
placement.  On discharge, your heart rate had improved control
on several new medications.
.
Please weigh yourself every morning, call your doctor if weight
goes up more than 3 lbs.
.
Please get your sodium and potassium checked the next time you
see a doctor
.
We have made the following changes to your medications:
-STOP Hydrochlorothiazide
-STOP Carvedilol
-CHANGE Warfarin to 5 mg daily
-START Furosemide 40 mg, once daily
-START Aspirin 81 mg, once daily
-START Metoprolol Succinate 150 mg, once daily
-START Potassium chloride 20meq daily
-START Miconazole powder applied twice daily AS NEEDED for your
rash
.
Please follow up with your primary care physician, [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **].[**Last Name (STitle) 2204**],
and your cardiologist, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 73**], as below.
.
We wish you all the best!

Followup Instructions:

.
